instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3332: What is 820-3332? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U8900: What is U8900? This chip creates the GPU power rails on the 820-3332 board to the 2012 and early 2013 15” Retina Macbook Pros. It becomes desoldered and is the cause of no video and kernel panics/crashes in that model most of the time..
definitions.LCD_BKLT_EN: What is LCD_BKLT_EN? This is an enable signal. Anytime you see “_EN”, it means when the voltage is high(3.3 volts), whatever it is going to is being turned on or enabled. Here, “LCD_BKLT” which stands for “LCD screen backlight” is being enabled. This signal usually goes to an LED driver used for creating a power rail for the LCD screen backlight, to tell it to turn on & create this rail. .
definitions.LVDS_IG_BKL_ON: What is LVDS_IG_BKL_ON? LVDS_IG_BKL_ON is equivalent to LCD_BKLT_EN. This signal usually goes to an LED driver used for creating a power rail for the LCD screen backlight, to tell it to turn on & create this rail. .
definitions.R7020: What is R7020? Current sense shunt resistor for the charger, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 27/28 on ISL6259 should give you 20.02 ohms. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight
threads.message:
No History, Came from another store, had L9000 was missing, soldered it back: NOK
Displays on external HDMI screen OK
NVRAM Reset: NOK
Had Flux around <TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> area
No sign of WD but some few Test Points near <RESISTOR>R2655</RESISTOR> turned slightly brown like some screws holes contours......

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S0_LCDBKLT_FUSED</SIGNAL>:  12.56V
<SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>: 0V

<SIGNAL>IG_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> = <SIGNAL>LVDS_IG_BKL_ON</SIGNAL>: 0V
<SIGNAL>IG_LCD_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> = <SIGNAL>LVDS_IG_PANEL_PWR</SIGNAL>: 3.353V

<CHIP>U8900</CHIP> is powered properly:
<SIGNAL>PPVIN_S0_GFXIMVP</SIGNAL>: 12.56V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0_GFXIMVP</SIGNAL>: 5V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight
threads.message:
Do you get image on internal LCD?

If get external video, <CHIP>U8900</CHIP> is good for sure.

"L9000 was missing, soldered it back"
5V for sure at pins 28-30 of J9000?
Also check <SIGNAL>LCD_HPD</SIGNAL> level.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight
threads.message:
It's hard to tell if I have an image on the LCD screen as the apple Logo is not transparent on this model, so when I put my torch on the apple, I even can't see the light on the screen.
However I 've put the torch on the screen directly and for me there's no image on the screen.
I had No 5V at pins 28-30 of J9000.

I don't know what happened but the backlight came back for no reason.......

I've reassembled the machine did few tries, it's like when the machine is upside down it's working properly but not everytime when in normal position.....

Also I've turned off the machine normally from the OS, tried to turn it back ON, it displayed the red low battery logo ( which means backlight OK ) with the fans spinning few seconds.....and this with the battery fully charged at 100%.
This machine is acting weird:
I've plugged the charger and turned ON properly with the backlight OK and the battery back at 100%....then the backlight went off....
this machine has really a strange behaviour.....

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight
threads.message:
After different test I think that it's not a backlight issue but a CPU issue as I've noticed that when the backlight turns OFF I'm loosing the Image also.
I've noticed that sometimes, when I'm trying to turn OFF the machine from the OS, the Image and backlight turns OFF but the fans stay spining and S0 state is still present, I've to press the power button or disconnect the battery to turn OFF the machine....
So I'll focus more on the CPU and see if I can find something........

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight
threads.message:
When this issue happens during the shutdown, I told you that S0 state was present, sorry but it's only present for CPU VCore, but I have no rail present for the GPU S0 states:
At those coils I have no power: L8360,L8310,L8930,L8960,L7550,L7560.

I'm looking for the common point of all those rails.......

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight
threads.message:
I'm quit lost on this issue, and I don't really understand how the display/backlight is managed by this architecture......
I've noticed that even withh the display/backlight working, I have NO power on those GPU  Coils/Rails I've mensionned before......2Informaticos could you please explain me (us) how it works on those machines with <CHIP>U8900</CHIP>, <CHIP>U8000</CHIP> <CHIP>U9100</CHIP> please?
Which one is doing what in which order/ sequence.....thank you

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight
threads.message:
"I had No 5V at pins 28-30 of J9000."
In such case, no image possible; also no backlight, of course.

Be sure to use original charger and check <SIGNAL>SM_LID</SIGNAL> signal.

"could you please explain me (us) how it works"
The forum is most for repair assistance.
Louis staff provide online training, as in person too.
Many times I explain things on the forum, but training is better person-to-person...
